body: How about just `its(:email)`?
i am fine with that, is that supposed to be working currently?

My first try, I couldn't come up with anything DRYer : /

How could we improve this?

http://gist.github.com/588711

Now that I see that implementation (which is fine, btw, relax!), I think we need to go with your original idea: `its('[:email]')`, to avoid the case where someone wants to say `its(:keys)` :)

Or maybe just `its([:email])`, without the quotes. WDYT?

I've gone with your array approach, since it intuitively suggests nested attributes  :)  (like its([:nested, :attribute])
And that way I've got rid of that killer map.inject.ad_infinitum too!

http://gist.github.com/588711

But I still don't like the if : /
Is there any alternate approach?

I'm re-thinking whether I want to include this. I definitely don't want to support nested attributes. As it is, `its` already feels like DRY at the expense of expressiveness to me, but that takes it to a new level. Plus, it would lead to more requests for nested structures including Arrays. Don't want to head down that path.

You said you were looking to DRY things up in the original post in this issue. Can you show me an example? Give me a before and after, and also what the output would look like in either case.

Here's my new approach: using an OStruct to enable regular message-sending to the Hash. Neither nested attributes nor much extra code, just one line (requiring 'ostruct' though).

http://gist.github.com/588711
This implementation is in http://github.com/txus/rspec-core/commit/bd0f6d8b841055cee84490c706f1b6af9ef99357
That's fine. My concern is that `its(:keys)` will see that the subject is a Hash and look for a key named `:keys`. Make sense?
ah yeah true.
Given that complication, what's your thought? Should we bag this, or go with one of the earlier syntax options?

I think doing something with brackets is the best option honestly. It communicates that its a hash but still allows for errors to list out like "its [:stupid] expected to be X but was Y". I think masking the [] syntax is not really desirable since it adds rspec magic that isnt really necessary.
Agreed.

What about adding an additional check that ensures the attribute is not specific of the Enumerable or Hash methods? (e.g. :keys, :values, :first...)

http://gist.github.com/588711

I think that's confusing because now its(:keys) and its(:some_key) look similar but have different semantics.

I think its(:keys) and its([:some_key]) is the most expressive so far.

Another option would be `its(key(:foo))`.

WDYT?

In fact with this implementation the its([:attribute]) - its(:keys) works. The only issue with this is that you can do either "its(:attribute)" and "its([:attribute])" and it has the same effect (which is ambiguous).

Would you suggest maybe that only when the 'attribute' is an array ([:something]) it should be referring to an attribute, and in any other case it should be treated as a regular method? If so, its(:keys) would refer to the hash keys, its([:attribute]) would do hash[:attribute] and (most importantly) its(:attribute) would fail with a no method error because a Hash doesn't have such method. Here's how it may look:

http://gist.github.com/588711

That seems right. Go for it.

Thx
